Colors & Palettes

Complete guide to the CPAL color system

Overview

The cpaltemplates color system provides 21 functions for working with CPAL’s carefully designed color palettes. All colors are sourced from _brand.yml and designed for WCAG accessibility compliance.

Primary Brand Colors

CPAL’s 5 core brand colors form the foundation of all palettes:

Show code 
cpal_colors_primary()
 midnight deep_teal     coral      sage     slate warm_gray 
"#004855" "#006878" "#E86A50" "#5A8A6F" "#5C6B73" "#9BA8AB"
Color Hex Code Use Case
Midnight #004855; border-radius: 3px; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 8px; border: 1px solid #ddd;'>#004855 Dark backgrounds, headers, primary emphasis
Deep Teal #006878; border-radius: 3px; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 8px; border: 1px solid #ddd;'>#006878 Primary brand color, links, info states
Coral #E86A50; border-radius: 3px; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 8px; border: 1px solid #ddd;'>#E86A50 Accents, alerts, negative/error states
Sage #5A8A6F; border-radius: 3px; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 8px; border: 1px solid #ddd;'>#5A8A6F Success states, positive indicators
Slate #5C6B73; border-radius: 3px; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 8px; border: 1px solid #ddd;'>#5C6B73 Secondary text, borders, muted elements
Warm Gray #9BA8AB; border-radius: 3px; vertical-align: middle; margin-right: 8px; border: 1px solid #ddd;'>#9BA8AB Neutral backgrounds, disabled states

Core Color Functions

cpal_colors()

The main entry point for accessing any CPAL color or palette.

Show code 
# Get all primary colors
cpal_colors()
 midnight deep_teal     coral      sage     slate warm_gray 
"#004855" "#006878" "#E86A50" "#5A8A6F" "#5C6B73" "#9BA8AB"
Show code 
# Get a single color by name
cpal_colors("coral")
    coral 
"#E86A50"
Show code 
# Get multiple specific colors
cpal_colors(c("midnight", "coral", "sage"))
 midnight     coral      sage 
"#004855" "#E86A50" "#5A8A6F"
Show code 
# Get a palette
cpal_colors("midnight_seq_5")
[1] "#E8F4F6" "#88BECA" "#28889E" "#006D88" "#004855"
Show code 
# Limit number of colors
cpal_colors("main", n = 3)
[1] "#004855" "#E86A50" "#5A8A6F"
Show code 
# Reverse palette order
cpal_colors("midnight_seq_5", reverse = TRUE)
[1] "#004855" "#006D88" "#28889E" "#88BECA" "#E8F4F6"

cpal_colors_extended()

Returns all 17+ colors including primary colors and shades:

Show code 
cpal_colors_extended()
  midnight  deep_teal      coral       sage      slate  warm_gray       teal 
 "#004855"  "#006878"  "#E86A50"  "#5A8A6F"  "#5C6B73"  "#9BA8AB"  "#007A8C" 
      gold       plum coral_dark    neutral midnight_1 midnight_2 midnight_3 
 "#B8860B"  "#8B5E83"  "#C75540"  "#E8ECEE"  "#E8F4F6"  "#B8D9E0"  "#88BECA" 
midnight_4 midnight_5 midnight_6 midnight_7 midnight_8    success    warning 
 "#58A3B4"  "#28889E"  "#006D88"  "#004855"  "#002D38"  "#5A8A6F"  "#D4A84B" 
     error       info 
 "#C75540"  "#006878"

Viewing Palettes

All Available Palettes

Show code 
list_cpal_palettes()
 [1] "primary"          "main"             "main_3"           "main_4"          
 [5] "main_5"           "main_6"           "blues"            "compare"         
 [9] "binary"           "status"           "midnight_seq_4"   "midnight_seq_5"  
[13] "midnight_seq_6"   "midnight_seq_8"   "coral_midnight_3" "coral_midnight_5"
[17] "coral_midnight_7" "coral_midnight_9" "main_gray"        "teal_seq_5"      
[21] "pink_teal_5"

Visual Palette Display

Show code 
view_cpal_palettes()

Palette Types

Categorical Palettes

For discrete data with distinct categories:

Show code 
view_cpal_palettes(c("main", "main_3", "main_4", "main_5", "main_6", "binary", "status"))

Usage example:

Show code 
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = factor(cyl), fill = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_bar() +
  scale_fill_cpal("main_3") +
  labs(title = "Count by Cylinder", x = "Cylinders", y = "Count") +
  theme_cpal() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

Sequential Palettes

For continuous or ordered data:

Show code 
view_cpal_palettes(c("midnight_seq_4", "midnight_seq_5", "midnight_seq_6", "midnight_seq_8"))

Usage example:

Show code 
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = hp)) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  scale_color_cpal_c("midnight_seq_5") +
  labs(
    title = "Fuel Efficiency by Weight",
    subtitle = "Color shows horsepower",
    x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    y = "Miles per Gallon",
    color = "Horsepower"
  ) +
  theme_cpal()

Diverging Palettes

For data with a meaningful midpoint:

Show code 
view_cpal_palettes(c("coral_midnight_3", "coral_midnight_5", "coral_midnight_7", "coral_midnight_9"))

Usage example:

Show code 
# Create sample data with positive and negative changes
change_data <- data.frame(
  category = LETTERS[1:7],
  change = c(-15, -8, -2, 0, 5, 12, 20)
)

ggplot(change_data, aes(x = category, y = change, fill = change)) +
  geom_col() +
  scale_fill_gradient2(
    low = "#E86A50",
    mid = "#E8ECEE",
    high = "#004855",
    midpoint = 0
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Year-over-Year Change",
    x = "Category",
    y = "Change (%)"
  ) +
  theme_cpal() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

ggplot2 Scale Functions

Discrete Scales

Show code 
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_cpal("main_3") +
  labs(
    title = "Discrete Color Scale",
    color = "Cylinders"
  ) +
  theme_cpal()

Continuous Scales

Show code 
ggplot(faithfuld, aes(waiting, eruptions, fill = density)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_cpal_c("teal_seq_5") +
  labs(title = "Continuous Fill Scale") +
  theme_cpal()

Color Interpolation

cpal_color_ramp()

Generate smooth gradient between two colors:

Show code 
# Gradient from coral to midnight
cpal_color_ramp("coral", "midnight", n = 7)
[1] "#E86A50" "#C16450" "#9A5E51" "#745952" "#4D5353" "#264D54" "#004855"
Show code 
# Using color names from brand.yml
cpal_color_ramp("midnight_1", "midnight", n = 5)
[1] "#E8F4F6" "#AEC9CD" "#749EA5" "#39737D" "#004855"

cpal_color_gradient()

Create gradient through multiple colors:

Show code 
# Three-color gradient
cpal_color_gradient(c("coral", "neutral", "midnight"), n = 9)
[1] "#E86A50" "#E88A77" "#E8AB9F" "#E8CBC6" "#E8ECEE" "#AEC3C7" "#749AA1"
[8] "#39717B" "#004855"

Color Validation (Accessibility)

validate_color_contrast()

Check if two colors meet WCAG contrast requirements:

Show code 
# Check deep_teal on white (should pass AA)
validate_color_contrast("#006878", "#FFFFFF")
$foreground
[1] "#006878"

$background
[1] "#FFFFFF"

$contrast_ratio
[1] 6.46

$level
[1] "AA"

$large_text
[1] FALSE

$threshold
[1] 4.5

$passes
[1] TRUE

$recommendation
[1] "Passes WCAG AA (ratio: 6.46:1, required: 4.5:1)"
Show code 
# Check with AAA standard (stricter)
validate_color_contrast("#006878", "#FFFFFF", level = "AAA")
$foreground
[1] "#006878"

$background
[1] "#FFFFFF"

$contrast_ratio
[1] 6.46

$level
[1] "AAA"

$large_text
[1] FALSE

$threshold
[1] 7

$passes
[1] FALSE

$recommendation
[1] "FAILS WCAG AAA (ratio: 6.46:1, required: 7.0:1). Consider using darker foreground or lighter background."
Show code 
# Midnight on white (high contrast)
validate_color_contrast("#004855", "#FFFFFF", level = "AAA")
$foreground
[1] "#004855"

$background
[1] "#FFFFFF"

$contrast_ratio
[1] 10.2

$level
[1] "AAA"

$large_text
[1] FALSE

$threshold
[1] 7

$passes
[1] TRUE

$recommendation
[1] "Passes WCAG AAA (ratio: 10.20:1, required: 7.0:1)"

validate_brand_colors()

Check all CPAL palette colors for accessibility:

Show code 
validate_brand_colors()

This function prints a detailed report showing which colors pass WCAG AA/AAA standards on white and dark backgrounds.

Choosing the Right Palette

Quick Reference

Data Type Recommended Palettes
Categories (≤3) main_3, binary
Categories (4-5) main_4, main_5
Categories (6-8) main_6, main
Sequential/Continuous midnight_seq_5, midnight_seq_6
Diverging (with midpoint) coral_midnight_5, coral_midnight_7
Binary comparison binary, compare
Status indicators status

Complete Example

Show code 
# Prepare data
car_data <- mtcars |>
  mutate(
    cylinders = factor(cyl),
    efficiency = ifelse(mpg > median(mpg), "High", "Low")
  )

# Create visualization
ggplot(car_data, aes(x = hp, y = mpg, color = cylinders, size = wt)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_cpal("main_3") +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(2, 8)) +
  labs(
    title = "Vehicle Performance Analysis",
    subtitle = "Fuel efficiency by horsepower, colored by cylinder count",
    x = "Horsepower",
    y = "Miles per Gallon",
    color = "Cylinders",
    size = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    caption = "Source: Motor Trend Car Road Tests (1974)"
  ) +
  theme_cpal()
